title: Nigel Farage and Alastair Campbell clash in epic TV shouting match over Brexit
text:
News Nigel Farage and Alastair Campbell clash in epic TV shouting match over Brexit Tony Blair's former spin doctor rebuffed the ex-Ukip leader's offer of lunch as a "waste of time" and cried: "We're gonna be a laughing stock!" Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Nigel Farage and Alastair Campbell clash over Brexit Share this video Get politics   Thank you for subscribing!   
Mega-Remainer Alastair Campbell and Brexiteer Nigel Farage tore strips off each other today as a TV clash descended into a shouting match. 
Tony Blair's former spin doctor rebuffed the ex-Ukip leader's offer of lunch as he warned Brexit Britain will be a "laughing stock". 
The pair - two of the most Marmite men in British politics - clashed on the sofa of ITV's Good Morning Britain. 
Their exchange left hosts Piers Morgan and Susanna Reid looking on with bemusement. 
Ms Reid tweeted: "At one point I thought the GMB bouncers were going to have to make an appearance." 
One Twitter user accused the pair of "acting like absolute children". 
Tory MP James Cleverly said: "They really are as bad as each other." Read More 
Right-winger Mr Farage first riled Mr Campbell by telling him: "The war is over. Come out of that fox hole." Tony Blair's former spin doctor said lunch with Farage would be a "waste of time" (Photo: ITV) Hosts Piers Morgan and Susanna Reid looked on, a little bemused (Photo: ITV) 
Mr Campbell, who has a new job at the pro-Remain New European newspaper, warned Britain had committed "an act of economic and political suicide". 
Mr Farage replied: “How is it political suicide to make your own laws in your own country? Do you loathe democracy so much? What is wrong with running your own country?” 
He added: "We're now getting our independence back, our pride back." Read More 
Mr Campbell rolled his eyes to the heavens and replied: "Pride back? Sorry, we're gonna be a laughing stock!" 
Mr Farage said: "I'll buy you lunch!" 
Mr Campbell hit back: "I don't want lunch, because lunch to me would be a waste of time when I could spend my time trying to stop this madness." 
Mr Farage insisted: “You’re not going to stop it, it’s all over, it’s done.” 
But Mr Campbell said: “Believe me, Brexit can be stopped.” Despite protests Article 50 will be triggered on Wednesday, formally starting Brexit (Photo: Barcroft Media) 
Mr Campbell's old boss Tony Blair, the Liberal Democrats and around 50 Labour MPs believe Brexit should not currently go ahead at all. 
Despite their wishes Theresa May will kick-start the two-year exit process by triggering Article 50 on Wednesday. Like us on Facebook
